awd_titl_txt: CPS:Synergy:Collaborative Research: Real-time Data Analytics for Energy Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Inadequate system understanding and inadequate situational awareness have caused large-scale power outages in the past.  With the increased reliance on variable energy supply sources, system understanding and situational awareness of a complex energy system become more challenging. This project leverages the power of big data analytics to directly improve system understanding and situational awareness. The research provides the methodology for detecting anomalous events in real-time, and therefore allow control centers to take appropriate control actions before minor events develop into major blackouts. The significance for the society and for the power industry is profound. Energy providers will be able to prevent large-scale power outages and reduce revenue losses, and customers will benefit from reliable energy delivery with service guarantees. Students, including women and underrepresented groups, will be trained for the future workforce in this area.

The project includes four major thrusts: 1) real-time anomaly detection from measurement data; 2) real-time event diagnosis and interpretation of changes in the state of the network; 3) real-time optimal control of the power grid; 4) scientific foundations underpinning cyber-physical systems. The major outcome of this project is practical solutions to event or fault detection and diagnosis in the power grid, as well as prediction and prevention of large-scale power outages.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Power systems generate a large amount of measurement data to analyze. With the increasing deployment of Phasor Management Units (PMUs), data will become too overwhelming for a human analyst. Human inspection is far behind in efficiency and accuracy for online event detection and diagnosis. It is therefore highly desirable to develop AI and machine learning tools and technologies towards automatic monitoring and control of the grid. Machine learning-based anomaly detection and identification directly improve situational awareness and system understanding. Real-time situational awareness enables dynamic switching of control states towards optimal control objectives.

For anomaly detection and identification, we developed machine learning algorithms that read in power grid measurement data and output the result of analysis: whether anomalous events have occurred, and if the answer is yes, what went wrong. A machine learning algorithm can produce the analysis results within milliseconds to meet the requirement of real-time data analytics.

A major challenge for developing such AI technologies is that a small amount of ?event? data are buried in a massive amount of ?normal? data. Due to the dynamic nature of the measurement data, there is no fixed baseline for normality. Training a classification algorithm from extremely imbalanced datasets is challenging. If the objective is to achieve the best overall accuracy, the algorithm can result in poor performance in the rare class. We developed an algorithm that achieved the best tradeoff between the rare class and the main class, i.e., at the same true positive rate, it has the lowest false positive rate in comparison with other algorithms; or, at the same false positive rate, it has highest true positive rate.

Anomalies in the power grid can be the results of natural failures or deliberate attacks. The anomaly detection and identification technologies not only improve the cyber physical system reliability but also advance the science for cyber-physical system security.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Maggie X Cheng
